articles.headline: Advanced U.S. Arms Make a Mark in Ukraine War, Officials Say
articles.snippet: The powerful and highly mobile weapons systems, which can fire guided rockets with a range of 40 miles, are desperately needed in the battle for eastern Ukraine.
articles.abstract: The powerful and highly mobile weapons systems, which can fire guided rockets with a range of 40 miles, are desperately needed in the battle for eastern Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The most advanced weapons that the United States has so far supplied Ukraine are making an impact in their first several days on the battlefield, destroying Russian ammunition depots and command centers, American and Ukrainian officials say.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and John Ismay

articles.headline: Inside the Extreme Effort to Punish Women for Abortion
articles.snippet: Abortion “abolitionists” are the outer edge of the anti-abortion movement. They’re looking to gain followers after the decision to overturn Roe, unsettling mainstream anti-abortion groups.
articles.abstract: Abortion “abolitionists” are the outer edge of the anti-abortion movement. They’re looking to gain followers after the decision to overturn Roe, unsettling mainstream anti-abortion groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hours after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade last week, a man with a wiry, squared-off beard and a metal cross around his neck celebrated with his team at a Brazilian steakhouse. He pulled out his phone to livestream to his followers.

articles.headline: Mark Zuckerberg Prepares Meta Employees for a Tougher 2022
articles.snippet: In an internal meeting this week, Mr. Zuckerberg said the tech giant was facing one of the “worst downturns that we’ve seen in recent history.”
articles.abstract: In an internal meeting this week, Mr. Zuckerberg said the tech giant was facing one of the “worst downturns that we’ve seen in recent history.”
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Mark Zuckerberg has a message for Meta employees: Buckle up for tough times ahead.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Sheera Frenkel

articles.headline: Trump Eyes Early 2024 Announcement as Jan. 6 Scrutiny Intensifies
articles.snippet: Donald Trump has accelerated his campaign planning, hoping a White House bid will blunt a series of damaging revelations. Some Republicans are worried.
articles.abstract: Donald Trump has accelerated his campaign planning, hoping a White House bid will blunt a series of damaging revelations. Some Republicans are worried.
articles.lead_paragraph: Republicans are bracing for Donald J. Trump to announce an unusually early bid for the White House, a move designed in part to shield the former president from a stream of damaging revelations emerging from investigations into his attempts to cling to power after losing the 2020 election.
articles.byline: By Michael C. Bender, Reid J. Epstein and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Ill Prepared for Combat, Volunteers Die in Battles Far From Home
articles.snippet: Many of the fighters for Ukraine’s western territorial defense units were assigned benign tasks away from the fighting when they first joined. Then they were called to the front to fight.
articles.abstract: Many of the fighters for Ukraine’s western territorial defense units were assigned benign tasks away from the fighting when they first joined. Then they were called to the front to fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: RUDNE, Ukraine — Yurii Brukhal, an electrician by trade, did not have a very dangerous role when he volunteered for Ukraine’s territorial defense forces at the start of the war. He was assigned to make deliveries and staff a checkpoint in the relative safety of his sleepy village.

articles.headline: The Federal Government Subsidizes Abortions. Will That Last?
articles.snippet: Individuals can often use health insurance or flexible spending accounts to pay for abortions or deduct the cost on tax returns. Congress might weigh in.
articles.abstract: Individuals can often use health insurance or flexible spending accounts to pay for abortions or deduct the cost on tax returns. Congress might weigh in.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the United States, you can get a tax deduction for your abortion if your overall health care expenses are high enough. That didn’t change with the Supreme Court’s ruling last week.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard

articles.headline: Did the Supreme Court Open the Door to Reviving One of Its Worst Decisions?
articles.snippet: Lochner v. New York, a 1905 decision on labor law, is imprinted on today’s law students as an example of bad jurisprudence. But those old days could be returning.
articles.abstract: Lochner v. New York, a 1905 decision on labor law, is imprinted on today’s law students as an example of bad jurisprudence. But those old days could be returning.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the annals of the Supreme Court, few opinions have been more reviled than the 1905 decision in Lochner v. New York.

articles.headline: When Where You Work Determines if You Can Get an Abortion
articles.snippet: After the Dobbs v. Jackson decision, many women are discovering that their employer can shape major decisions in their lives even more than it did a week ago.
articles.abstract: After the Dobbs v. Jackson decision, many women are discovering that their employer can shape major decisions in their lives even more than it did a week ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Breanna Dietrich was 18 and working at a restaurant in West Virginia, she got pregnant. The father was a man she knew she wouldn’t marry. She considered getting an abortion. But the nearest clinic was four hours away and she couldn’t afford to take off work — so she had the baby girl.

articles.headline: Spurred by the Supreme Court, a Nation Divides Along a Red-Blue Axis
articles.snippet: On abortion, climate change, guns and much more, two Americas — one liberal, one conservative — are moving in opposite directions.
articles.abstract: On abortion, climate change, guns and much more, two Americas — one liberal, one conservative — are moving in opposite directions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pressed by Supreme Court decisions diminishing rights that liberals hold dear and expanding those cherished by conservatives, the United States appears to be drifting apart into separate nations, with diametrically opposed social, environmental and health policies.

articles.headline: Skyrocketing Global Fuel Prices Threaten Livelihoods and Social Stability
articles.snippet: Around the world, from South Asia and Africa to Europe and Latin America, the cost of filling a car’s tank, getting to work and cooking dinner has spiked.
articles.abstract: Around the world, from South Asia and Africa to Europe and Latin America, the cost of filling a car’s tank, getting to work and cooking dinner has spiked.
articles.lead_paragraph: “NO ES SUFICIENTE” — It’s not enough. That was the message protest leaders in Ecuador delivered to the country’s president this past week after he said he would lower the price of both regular gas and diesel by 10 cents in response to riotous demonstrations over soaring fuel and food prices.

articles.headline: Gridlock in Congress Has Amplified the Power of the Supreme Court
articles.snippet: What was once a dialogue between the branches has become almost entirely one-sided, with the justices accumulating clout at lawmakers’ expense.
articles.abstract: What was once a dialogue between the branches has become almost entirely one-sided, with the justices accumulating clout at lawmakers’ expense.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the last day of a turbulent term that included rulings on what the Constitution has to say about abortion, guns and religion, the Supreme Court issued another sort of decision, one that turned on the words of the Clean Air Act.

articles.headline: The Long Path to Reclaim Abortion Rights
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court decision to reverse Roe, far from settling the matter, instead has launched court and political battles across the states likely to go on for years.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court decision to reverse Roe, far from settling the matter, instead has launched court and political battles across the states likely to go on for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Attempting to recover from their staggering loss in the Supreme Court, abortion rights groups have mounted a multilevel legal and political attack aimed at blocking and reversing abortion bans in courts and at ballot boxes across the country.

articles.headline: Once a Crucial Refuge, ‘Gayborhoods’ Lose L.G.B.T.Q. Residents in Major Cities
articles.snippet: Many are choosing to live elsewhere in search of cheaper housing and better amenities. They are finding growing acceptance in other communities after decades of political and social changes.
articles.abstract: Many are choosing to live elsewhere in search of cheaper housing and better amenities. They are finding growing acceptance in other communities after decades of political and social changes.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Cleve Jones has lived in the Castro neighborhood for nearly 50 years, almost from the day he graduated from high school in Phoenix and hitchhiked to California.

articles.headline: ‘The Pro-Life Generation’: Young Women Fight Against Abortion Rights
articles.snippet: Many American women mourned the Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe, but for others it is a moment of triumph and a matter of human rights.
articles.abstract: Many American women mourned the Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe, but for others it is a moment of triumph and a matter of human rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — The rollback of abortion rights has been received by many American women with a sense of shock and fear, and warnings about an ominous decline in women’s status as full citizens.

articles.headline: 76 Fake Charities Shared a Mailbox. The I.R.S. Approved Them All.
articles.snippet: The tax agency is the gatekeeper for America’s charity system, but reduced vetting has opened the door to scams.
articles.abstract: The tax agency is the gatekeeper for America’s charity system, but reduced vetting has opened the door to scams.
articles.lead_paragraph: The “American Cancer Society of Michigan,” state authorities say, was a fake charity. And not even a good fake.
articles.byline: By David A. Fahrenthold, Troy Closson and Julie Tate

articles.headline: 3-D Printing Grows Beyond Its Novelty Roots
articles.snippet: With the technology improving and costs falling, 3-D printing could be poised to play a major role in manufacturing.
articles.abstract: With the technology improving and costs falling, 3-D printing could be poised to play a major role in manufacturing.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEVENS, Mass. — The machines stand 20 feet high, weigh 60,000 pounds and represent the technological frontier of 3-D printing.

articles.headline: An American’s Murky Path From Russian Propagandist to Jan. 6
articles.snippet: Charles Bausman, a former financial executive who runs websites that promote far-right views, recorded footage in the Capitol for a Russian television producer. Soon after, he fled to Moscow as a “political refugee.”
articles.abstract: Charles Bausman, a former financial executive who runs websites that promote far-right views, recorded footage in the Capitol for a Russian television producer. Soon after, he fled to Moscow as a “political refugee.”
articles.lead_paragraph: In security footage from Jan. 6, it is easy to overlook the thin man wearing a red Trump hat who filters into the U.S. Capitol Building to record the mayhem with his phone.

articles.headline: As City Falls, Ukraine’s Last Hope in Luhansk Falls With It
articles.snippet: Lysychansk managed to hold out for a week after its twin city, Sievierodonetsk, was captured. But on Sunday a pro-Russian flag flew there, as well.
articles.abstract: Lysychansk managed to hold out for a week after its twin city, Sievierodonetsk, was captured. But on Sunday a pro-Russian flag flew there, as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: The last major city held by Ukraine in the heavily contested eastern province of Luhansk has fallen, military officials on both sides said Sunday, giving Moscow a milestone victory in its campaign to capture the Donbas, the mineral-rich region bordering Russia that has long been in President Vladimir V. Putin’s sights.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Kamila Hrabchuk and Vivian Yee

articles.headline: In Ukraine, U.S. Veterans Step In Where the Military Will Not
articles.snippet: Special Operations veterans are training Ukrainians near the front lines in the fight against Russia, despite warnings from the Pentagon.
articles.abstract: Special Operations veterans are training Ukrainians near the front lines in the fight against Russia, despite warnings from the Pentagon.
articles.lead_paragraph: A democracy came under attack. The United States saw a threat to an ally and also to the entire world order, but it feared that sending troops could spark a nuclear war. So, instead, it supplied weapons. And a small number of American Special Operations trainers started quietly working with the local military.

articles.headline: New Insights Into Trump’s State of Mind on Jan. 6 Chip Away at Doubts
articles.snippet: Former President Donald J. Trump has weathered scandals by keeping his intentions under wraps, but recent testimony paints a stark portrait of a man willing to do almost anything to hang onto power.
articles.abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump has weathered scandals by keeping his intentions under wraps, but recent testimony paints a stark portrait of a man willing to do almost anything to hang onto power.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He was not speaking metaphorically. It was not an offhand comment. President Donald J. Trump had every intention of joining a mob of supporters he knew to be armed and dangerous as it marched to the Capitol. And there had even been talk of marching into the House chamber himself to disrupt Congress from ratifying his election defeat.
